content.question: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A Lewis electron-dot diagram of the oxalate ion, <math alttext="C 2 O 4, with a negative 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mrow><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo></mrow></msup></math>, is shown. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of either carbon atom in the oxalate ion.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. A Lewis electron-dot diagram of the oxalate ion, <math alttext="C 2 O 4, with a negative 2 charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mrow><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>-</mo></mrow></msup></math>, is shown. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of either carbon atom in the oxalate ion.

(b) Silver oxalate, <math alttext="A g 2 C 2 O 4, solid" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>, is slightly soluble in water. The value of <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="A g 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub></math> is <math alttext="5.40 times 10 to the negative 12 power" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.40</mn><mo>Ã—</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></msup></math>. (i) Write the expression for the solubility-product constant, <math alttext="K s p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, for <math alttext="A g 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub></math>. (ii) Calculate the molar solubility of <math alttext="A g 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub></math> in neutral distilled water. (iii) The molar solubility of <math alttext="A g 2 C 2 O 4" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub></math> increases when it is dissolved in <math alttext="0.5 molar H C l O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0.5</mn> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <mi>M</mi> <mo> </mo> <mo> </mo> <msub> <mi>HClO</mi> <mn>4</mn> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo> <mi>a</mi> <mi>q</mi> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </math> instead of neutral distilled water. Write a balanced, net-ionic equation for the process that occurs between species in solution that contributes to the increased solubility of <math alttext="A g 2 C 2 O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>Ag</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>C</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mtext>O</mtext><mn>4</mn></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mtext>)</mtext></math> in <math alttext="H C l O 4, aqueous" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>HClO</mi><mn>4</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>.

skill.text: 1.A: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate particulate-level properties only.
